section1.title: DOES YOUR HOTEL HAVE TO CLOSE FOR LONG PERIODS EACH YEAR?
section1.content: Most hotels have certain periods during the year when demand drops significantly, leading to partial or full closures. By adopting a flexible living model, you will keep rooms filled during these low seasons, stabilizing income and improving operational efficiency year-round.

section2.title: BUILD A MODEL THAT GUARANTEES FULL OCCUPANCY
section2.content: The key to sustained success is stable, predictable revenue and full rooms‚Äîeven during historically low occupancy months. Structure rates and packages so that "living" guests fill gaps left by transient guests without undermining your regular pricing.

section3.title: USE AFFINITIES TO DIFFERENTIATE AND TARGET AUDIENCES
section3.content: Focus on niche audiences (artists, digital nomads, retirees, etc.) to avoid competing directly with standard hotel offerings and OTAs. Use affinities to build loyal, recurring client groups adapted to your category (see "Themes" section).

section4.title: ADAPT LENGTH OF STAY TO HOTEL SIZE AND DYNAMICS
section4.content: Smaller hotels may benefit from longer minimum stays (e.g., 1‚Äì3 months), reducing turnover cost. Larger hotels can experiment with rotations‚Äîe.g., "9 nights per month club"‚Äîto optimize for higher volume and guest experience.

section5.title: LEVERAGE BOUTIQUE CONCEPTS FOR SMALL HIGH-END HOTELS
section5.content: If you manage a boutique or luxury hotel, design tailored experiences (wellness, culture, business retreats) with premium rates. These can be highly attractive to remote professionals or guests seeking exclusivity and added value.

section6.title: APPLY VOLUME LOGIC FOR LARGER HOTELS
section6.content: Larger properties can tap into "living at scale" logic‚Äîdiscounts for recurring guests, flexible plans (e.g., alternate weeks), and partnerships with institutions or companies to fill blocks of rooms efficiently.

section7.title: UNDERSTAND THE POWER OF RECURRING STAYS AND CUSTOMER ROTATION
section7.content: Monthly, multi-month, or club-style stays (where guests return on set days each month) increase forecastability while giving guests "home" status. This increases loyalty and can transform your hotel's business model in a predictable, positive way.

section8.title: NOBODY KNOWS YOUR HOTEL BETTER THAN YOU DO
section8.content: Use your in-depth experience to build a living-stay model adapted to your specific reality, cultural context, and clientele. No generic formula beats your understanding of your business's unique seasonality and potential.
